title: 104_hr199
content: The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act of 1995" allows for a depreciation adjustment for certain property placed in service after December 31, 1994. The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act of 1995" allows for a deduction adjustment to allow the equivalent of expensing for tangible property placed in service after December 31, 1994. This amendment modifies the deduction under Section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code by substituting '150 percent' for '200 percent' in certain cases. The Neutral Cost Recovery Act of 1995 allows for a deduction adjustment for tangible property placed in service after December 31, 1994. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for the property in any taxable year is determined by dividing the gross domestic product deflator for that year. The Neutral Cost Recovery Act of 1995 allows for a deduction adjustment for tangible property placed in service after December 31, 1994. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio is determined by multiplying the gross domestic product deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service by 1.035 to the power of the number of full years since the property was placed in service. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio is determined based on the gross domestic product deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service. The ratio will never be less than 1 and will be rounded to the nearest \1/1000\. Special rules apply for certain types of property. The gross domestic product deflator for any calendar quarter is the implicit price deflator for the gross domestic product for that quarter. Taxpayers can elect not to have this subsection apply to their property, and once the election is made, it is irrevocable. Churning transactions are exempt from this subsection if certain conditions are met. The additional deduction under this section does not affect the property's basis or recapture. The subsection excludes certain deductions from being considered in property's adjusted basis or depreciation deductions for specific entities like regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds. Additionally, there are amendments to the minimum tax treatment under section 56(a) of the Code. The amendment to section 56(a) of the Code allows for the use of a neutral cost recovery ratio for property subject to section 168(k) placed in service after December 31, 1994. This ratio is applied to the deduction allowable for such property in each taxable year. The amendment allows for a neutral cost recovery deduction for property under section 168(k) and coordinates with the depreciation limitation on certain automobiles. The amendments made by this section allow for a neutral cost recovery deduction for property under section 168(k) and coordinate with the depreciation limitation on certain automobiles. These amendments apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 1994. SEC. 3. INCREASE IN EXPENSE TREATMENT FOR SMALL BUSINESSES. The dollar limitation under section 179(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is raised from $17,500 to $25,000 for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1995.
